for short file transfer protocol or FTP for short

idioms.text: at short notice | at a moment’s notice (North American English also on short notice)
idioms.sense: not long in advance; without warning or time for preparation
examples: This was the best room we could get at such short notice.
You must be ready to leave at a moment's notice.
It's the best we can do at such short notice.
The team is ready to go anywhere in the world at a moment's notice.

idioms.text: a brick short of a load, two sandwiches short of a picnic, etc.
idioms.sense: stupid; not very intelligent
the whole of something or less of something than you expect or should have
examples: We experienced the full measure of their hospitality.
The concert only lasted an hour, so we felt we were getting short measure.

idioms.text: get the short end of the stick (North American English) (British English draw the short straw)
idioms.sense: to be the person in a group who is chosen or forced to perform an unpleasant duty or task

idioms.text: give somebody/something short shrift | get short shrift
idioms.sense: to give somebody little attention or sympathy; to get little attention or sympathy
to tend to get angry quickly and easily
to become angry easily
used to describe what will happen a long, short, etc. time in the future
examples: Such a development seems unlikely, at least in the short term (= it will not happen for quite a long time).
In the longer term, children of depressed mothers are more likely to suffer from childhood depression.
In the long term, our efforts will pay off.

idioms.sense: quickly and without trouble
relating to the immediate future
examples: In the short run, unemployment may fall.

idioms.sense: not existing in large enough quantities to satisfy demand
examples: Basic foodstuffs were in short supply.
Sunshine will be in short supply for the west coast.
Safe drinking water is in desperately short supply.

idioms.sense: (still) only a boy
examples: I was still in short trousers at the time.

idioms.sense: used to say that it is not worth wasting time doing something that you dislike or that is not important
examples: Life's too short to sit around moping.

idioms.sense: used when you are saying that something is almost true, or is equal to something
examples: Last year's figures were little short of disastrous.
The transformation has been nothing short of a miracle.

idioms.text: (to cut a) long story short (British English) (North American English (to make a) long story short)
idioms.sense: used when you are saying that you will get to the point of what you are saying quickly, without including all the details
examples: To cut a long story short, we didn’t get home until 3 in the morning!
Anyway, long story short: we had this argument and I haven't seen him since.

idioms.sense: to defeat, deal with something/somebody quickly
examples: Liverpool made short work of the opposition (= in a football match).
He made short work of his lunch (= ate it quickly).
Mike made short work of fixing the engine.

idioms.sense: not lasting a long time but pleasant while it lasts
examples: We haven't much time so I'll keep it short and sweet.

idioms.sense: very stupid

senses.text: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
examples: see somebody/something She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.

see what, how, etc… Did you see what happened?

see somebody/something + adj. I hate to see you unhappy.
see somebody/something doing something She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.
see somebody/something do something I saw you put the key in your pocket.
somebody/something is seen to do something He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.
(figurative) The government not only has to do something, it must be seen to be doing something (= people must be aware that it is doing something).
see + adv./prep. The walls were too high to see over.

see something Did you see that programme on Brazil last night?

idioms.sense: to support and agree with somebody
examples: I'm definitely on your side in this.
Whose side are you on anyway?

idioms.sense: the boyfriend or girlfriend of somebody who is already married or in a steady sexual relationship with somebody else
examples: Is he your bit on the side?

idioms.text: come down on one side of the fence or the other
idioms.sense: to choose between two possible choices

idioms.text: err on the side of something
idioms.sense: to show too much of a good quality in order to avoid showing too little
examples: I thought it was better to err on the side of caution (= to be too careful rather than take a risk).

idioms.sense: moving to the left and then to the right and then back again
examples: He shook his head slowly from side to side.
The ship rolled from side to side.
The cat sat with its tail twitching from side to side.

idioms.text: from/on the wrong side of the tracks
idioms.sense: from or living in a poor area or part of town

idioms.text: get on the right/wrong side of somebody
idioms.sense: to make somebody pleased with you/annoyed with you

idioms.text: get out of bed on the wrong side (British English) (North American English get up on the wrong side of the bed)
idioms.sense: to be in a bad mood for the whole day for no particular reason

idioms.text: the grass is (always) greener on the other side (of the fence)
idioms.sense: said about people who never seem happy with what they have and always think they could be happier in a different place or situation
to have something as an advantage that will make it more likely that you will achieve something
examples: She may not win this year, but she does have youth on her side.

idioms.text: know which side your bread is buttered
idioms.sense: to know where you can get an advantage for yourself

idioms.text: laugh on the other side of your face
idioms.sense: to be forced to change from feeling pleased or satisfied to feeling disappointed or annoyed
examples: He’ll be laughing on the other side of his face when he reads my letter.

idioms.sense: to fail to give your friends, family, etc. the help and support they expect, or to behave in a way that makes them disappointed
examples: You can always rely on Maggie—she’d never let the side down.

idioms.sense: to be cheerful or positive about a bad situation, for example by thinking only of the advantages and not the disadvantages
examples: Look on the bright side. You managed to do more than I did.

idioms.sense: to stay with somebody, especially in order to take care of them

idioms.text: on/from all sides | on/from every side
idioms.sense: in or from all directions; everywhere
examples: We realized we were surrounded on all sides.

idioms.text: on the big, small, high, etc. side
idioms.sense: slightly too big, small, high, etc.
examples: These shoes are a little on the tight side.

examples: On the credit side, she’s always willing to work very late.

idioms.sense: on the woman’s side of the family
out of your wayto be dealt with later
examples: I left my bags on one side.

being especially careful; taking no risks
examples: I took some extra cash just to be on the safe side.

idioms.sense: in addition to your main jobsecretly or illegallyserved at the same time as the main part of the meal, but on a separate plate

idioms.text: on the wrong side of the law
idioms.sense: in trouble with the police

idioms.text: the other side of the coin
idioms.sense: the aspect of a situation that is the opposite of or contrasts with the one you have been talking about
with the top part turned to the top; in the correct, normal position
examples: I dropped my toast, but luckily it fell right side up.

idioms.sense: close together and facing in the same directiontogether, without any difficulties
examples: There were two children ahead, walking side by side.

idioms.text: side of the fence (North American English also side of the aisle)

idioms.sense: to laugh a lot at somebody/something
to express support for somebody in an argument
examples: She didn't think it was wise to take sides in their argument.

idioms.sense: to speak to somebody in private, especially in order to warn or tell them about something
before a particular time, event, age, etc.
examples: They aren't likely to arrive this side of midnight.

idioms.sense: a person or thing that repeatedly annoys somebody or stops them from doing something
used to say that somebody can wait for something to happen or can wait before doing something

idioms.text: two sides of the same coin
idioms.sense: used to talk about two ways of looking at the same situation
